intro: Dalea goldmanii, commonly known as the golden prairie clover, is a flowering plant native to the central United States. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its erect, branched stems and small, showy yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in open prairies and dry, sandy soils, thriving in full sun. Its leaves are trifoliate, consisting of three oval-shaped leaflets, and it produces small, pod-like fruits that contain several seeds. Dalea goldmanii plays an important role in supporting pollinators and maintaining the ecological balance of its native habitats.
